results.title: The Queen Returns
results.creator_credit: Frank Bagnall, Stanley Hawes and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: The visit of Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth and His Royal Highness Prince Phillip to Australia. Much of the film is devoted to Canberra and its history as the Queen’s visit coincided with Canberra’s Jubilee Celebrations.

results.title: Professional Icing at Home
results.brief_description: Jean Bowring demonstrates how to decorate a birthday cake using simple equipment and techniques. A fruit cake is first covered with fondant icing and then decorated using an icing bag and assortment of tubes. The film concludes with examples of more elaborate work in which the same simple techniques of decoration have been used.

results.title: Port of Melbourne
results.creator_credit: Jennie Blackwood, Melbourne Harbor Trust Commissioners and Zanthus Films
results.brief_description: The Port of Melbourne and its behind-the-scenes organisation: the routing of a ship up river, the allocation of berths and tugs, harbour traffic control, cargo handling from ship to rail and road truck, future planning for the harbour, routine inspections and dredging and finally a first aid and rescue squad in action.

results.title: Planning for Melbourne's future
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Thompson, Melbourne and Metropolitan Board of Works and Cine Service
results.brief_description: In 1949 the Melbourne Metropolitan Board of Works was asked to formulate a plan that would estimate the future needs of Melbourne. From information gathered through surveys, inspecting every street and alley to determine its use, this was made possible. “Planning for Melbourne’s Future” is photographed and directed by Geoffrey Thompson and is an examination of this plan. It is a rare and honest account of the deficiencies and lack of planning made to prepare Melbourne for an increase in future population growth.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Geoffrey Thompson, Melbourne and Metropolitan Board of Works and Cine Service

results.title: Planning a city
results.brief_description: Sydney, the second greatest white city in the British Empire. A critical analysis of Sydney and the initial lack of city planning. Despite the surrounding beauty and the opportunity for wise planning, Sydney became a crowded and poorly serviced city. Many houses were built on narrow, cramped and dimly lit streets which contributed to the escalation of crime and disease. Those responsible for constructing roadways rarely considered the impact on residents. Many schools and shopping centres were built on major thoroughfares resulting in a high rate of school children and housewives being killed by cars. Considering the harbourside location, many of the views became obstructed by buildings housing the privileged. The ‘Town and Country Planning Act of 1945’ was introduced to provide an opportunity to remedy the mistakes of the past by planning for future improvements. This film includes scenes of Sydney as it was in the middle of this century and what is now historical footage of cars, buses, trams, trains, ferries and horse and carts.

results.title: Personal Hygiene For Boys (second edition)
results.brief_description: Designed to increase the understanding of personal hygiene - this film shows the importance of proper rest, diet and exercise to good health and appearance. It also deals with the special problems teenage boys have regarding personal hygiene and the changes taking place in their maturing bodies.

results.title: People make papers
results.brief_description: An outstanding film conveying impressions of one day in “The Age” newspaper office in Melbourne. This early film by noted Australian director Fred Schepisi, uses dramatic photography and natural sound to capture the atmosphere of the office, and records all the phases in the production of the paper: the collection of news stories, the lay-out, the printing and the eventual distribution. The camera work is by Peter Purvis.

results.title: The Other Face of the Island
results.creator_credit: John M. Bale, Norman Laird, Tasfilm Productions and Tasmania. Dept. of Film Production
results.brief_description: Using special cinematograph effects such as split screens, this film sets up a storyline to promote the resources and industries of Tasmania. The main products and secondary industries are grouped broadly into wool and textiles, including carpets; paper; processed food; and metal products. The cast includes four Australian models - Wendy Gilmore, Nola Clark, Carol Stevens and Barbara Wilding - outfitted by Prue Acton.

results.title: Operation and care of the RCA 400 16mm sound projector
results.creator_credit: Crawley Films and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description: Explains by use of close-up photography the threading, operation and care of the RCA 400 16 millimetre film and sound projector. Demonstrates the correct procedures for setting up and operating the equipment. Illustrates the packing up, cleaning and lubricating of the projector.

results.title: A Hundred-Odd Years From Now
results.creator_credit: Fred Schepisi, Australian Dried Fruits Association and Film House Company
results.brief_description: An advertising film with a difference: Into a strange computerised future where women “run things” by controlling huge colourful computers that go bleep booble bob bob ping etc, comes Yockoo, the boy from the bush, with his satchel of dried fruits. Slowly the women overcome their cold, futuristic ways in light of Yockoo’s size, shape and overall manliness. Eventually they unearth their deep feminine sexuality and cook Yockoo a feast of dried fruit dishes using cooking utensils from their local museum. Music by Frank Smith, Photographed by Lars Gundlach, Written and designed by Weatherhead & Stitt.
